docs.snippet: Fernando Collor de Mello resigned as President of Brazil today, ending eight months of political turmoil in Latin America's largest nation only minutes after the Brazilian Senate had begun an impeachment trial he was all but certain to lose.    Three...
docs.lead_paragraph: Fernando Collor de Mello resigned as President of Brazil today, ending eight months of political turmoil in Latin America's largest nation only minutes after the Brazilian Senate had begun an impeachment trial he was all but certain to lose. Three hours after the resignation, Vice President Itamar Franco was sworn in as President by the Brazilian Congress. Mr. Franco, a gentlemanly, little-known former Senator, is to serve out the rest of Mr. Collor's term, which ends in January 1995. [ Man in the News, page A8. ]

headline.main: BRAZILIAN LEADER QUITS AS HIS TRIAL STARTS IN SENATE

docs.snippet: In a studio on a quiet street here, there are striking paintings of the giant Amazonian anteater; Argentina's national tree, the ombu; lime-green dolphins, and upside-down maps of South America with rivers the only boundary demarcations and flowing...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a studio on a quiet street here, there are striking paintings of the giant Amazonian anteater; Argentina's national tree, the ombu; lime-green dolphins, and upside-down maps of South America with rivers the only boundary demarcations and flowing blood red. But the studio's owner, Nicolas Garcia Uriburu, Argentina's most noted environmental artist, has employed much larger canvases to convey his artistic message. Last fall, entering an inlet of water in the Buenos Aires port in an inflatable speedboat, he began dumping brick-red powder into the coffee-colored water, which immediately became laced with streaks of fluorescent green. The fountain in the middle of the inlet soon lifted the colored water, sending jets of green into the sky.
